transformer__string.contains.description:
Returns whether the input string contains the search string.
It accepts nil as an input and returns false in that case.

case_insensitive.description: Whether the search should be case insensitive.

transformer__kombo.current_posting.description:
Returns an item from the object data `job_postings` that satisfies the
following requirements:

* `visibility` is `"PUBLIC"`,
* `status` is `"ACTIVE"`
* `url` is a string.

The returned item may differ depending on the `post_url` value of the root
Kombo data object.

* If a satisfying job posting has the same `url` as the `post_url`, it is
  returned.
* Otherwise, the first satisfying job posting from the list is returned.
* Finally, this transformer will return `nil` if:
  * No job posting satisfies the requirements.
  * The `job_postings` list is empty.
  * The `job_postings` key is not a list.
  * The `job_postings` key does not exist.

source__digital_recruiters.jobs.description: DigitalRecruiters jobs API client with URL-based token and no pagination.

endpoint.description: The endpoint to fetch jobs from, uses `https://app.digitalrecruiters.com` if empty.

transformer__html.attribute.description:
Accepts an HTML string as input and returns a list of all values for the
`attribute` found on nodes selected with the `selector`.

Note that selected nodes that do not have such attribute are ignored.

Attributes with an empty value (as in `<input checked="" />`) or with no value
(as in `<input checked />`) will be returned as `""`.

attribute.description: The attribute name to fetch from the targetted nodes.

selector.description: A CSS selector to target HTML elements the attribute must be retrieved from.

target__core.noop.description:
A target that does nothing. It is useful for testing and debugging purposes.

Every load or unload operation will be successful, but no code is executed.

sleep.description: The number of milliseconds to spend to simulate the remote endpoint work time.

transformer__write_value.description: Writes the given value at the given key or path.

key.description: The key or path to store the input value in.

source__lever.jobs.description: This source implements the Lever postings API v0.

base_url.description: The Lever API endpoint, without the site name.

max_objects_per_page.description: Controls the pagination by setting the `limit` query parameter for each page.

query_string.description: An optional query string to support filtering at the source level.

site.description: The site name to add as a segment in the URL for the jobs.

transformer__write_key.description: Stores the input value in the data object at the given key.

key.description: The key or path to store the input value in.

nil_if_blank.description:
Write `nil` instead of the input when the input is an empty string or
a string that contains only whitespace characters.

transformer__string.concat.description:
Adds the `prefix` and or `suffix` to the given input, inserting the `glue` in
between.

Null prefixes or suffixes are treated as empty strings and are ignored. For
instance, if the `prefix` is null, the glue will not be added before the input
string.

Blank prefixes or suffixes are treated as empty strings and are ignored too.
That is, prefixes or suffixes that are only whitespace.

The glue is parsed as an escaped string, so `\\n` will be interpreted as a
`\n`, while `\n` still represent itself, both are treated the same way.

glue.description: The string between the input and the prefix/suffix

prefix.description: A piece of text to prepend before the input string

suffix.description: A piece of text to append after the input string

source__kombo.jobs.description: This source implements the Kombo API v1.

integration_id.description: The ID given on the integration details of the Kombo dashboard.

max_objects_per_page.description: Controls the pagination by setting the `page_size` query parameter for each page.

url.description: The url to override the default one.

visibilities_filter.description: Define the `visibilities` filter. This should generaly set to `PUBLIC`.

transformer__if.description:
This transformer is a macro transformer that allows conditional branching. It
will execute one of the `then` and `else` sequences depending on the input.

**Boolean rules**

* The input does not have to be a boolean. Any value will be converted to a
boolean depending whether it is _truthy_ or _falsy_.
* _Falsy_ values follow the rules of the Elixir language, that is, only
  `false` and `nil` (equivalent of JSON's `null`) are _falsy_.
* _Truthy_ values are everything else, including `0` (integer zero), `0.0`
  (float zero), and `""` (empty string).

**Input variable**

To use a value both in the `if` call and in the `then` or `else`
tranformations, one would have to:

* Assign the value to a variable,
* pass the variable to `if`,
* use the variable value in the `then` (or `else`).

The `input_var` param allows to skip the first step:

* Pass any value to the `if`, defining the `input_var` param to a name,
* use that variable name to read values.

Note that the defined variable will only exist within the `then` and `else`
transform sequences.

else.description: The sequence to execute if the input is a falsy value.

input_var.description:
A variable name that will be bound to the input given to `if` inside the
`then` and `else` transform sequences.

then.description: The sequence to execute if the input is a truthy value.

transformer__ai.detect_language.description:
Accepts a string or a list of string and tries to detect the language of the
given content.

The found language will be picked in a limited list of languages:
en, fr, pt, es, de, zh, it, cs.

transformer__render.mustache.description:
Executes the given template, using the input value as template variables.

The input data must be an object (a map).

The template uses the "mustache" syntax, _i.e_ wrapping variable names with
double curly braces.

The template has access to the object data under the `$data` variable.

**Example**

With the input defined as:

    {
      "user": {
        "name": "Joe"
      },
      "profession": "teacher"
    }

And the object data as:

    {
      "title": "Professeur d'Anglais H/F Paris"
    }

The template defined as:

    Hello {{ user.name }}. As a {{ profession }}, are you interested in {{ $data.title }}?

The output will be:

    Hello Joe. As a teacher, are you interested in Professeur d'Anglais H/F Paris?

template.description: The mustache template to execute with the given data.

transformer__string.append_key.description:
This transformer is deprecated. See `Concat`.

Appends the value identified by `key` to the given input, concatenated by the
`glue`.

* If the given input is `nil`, then the object value is returned, without the
  glue.
* If the `key` is not defined in the object, or contains an empty value (`nil`
  or a blank string) then the input value is returned, without the glue.
* If both are `nil`, an empty string is returned.

glue.description:
The string used to glue the input on the left and the object key value on
the right.

Note that is string is parsed for special characters, so giving `\n` will
be interpreted as a newline.

key.description: The key of the object whose value will be appended.

transformer__mapping.search_replace.description:
Uses a mapping data table to search for substrings or patterns in the input
value and replace them with their mapped value from the selected column.

The search is done following the mapping table entries ordering. For instance,
if two entries would replace "a" by "b" and "b" by "c", then all "a" would
be replaced by "c" in the end.

transformer__string.replace.description:
Searches for all occurences of `search` in the input and replaces them with
`replace`.

This transformer supports a `case_insensitive` option to make the search
case-insensitive, but note that the search and replacements are done at the
binary level, so rare inconsistencies may occur when dealing with multi-byte
characters.

**Using regular expressions:**

The `regex` parameter enable the regular expression mode where the `search`
paramater is treated as a regular expression. Regexes are compiled with the
`us` flags:

* `u` for unicode: advanced character classes are enabled, so for instance
  `\p{L}` will match any unicode letter (such as "Ã©") and not only ASCII
  characters (such as "e").
* `s` for _dotall_: The `.` character will match any character including
  newlines (`\n`), and the newline mode is set to `anycrlf` meaning that `.`
  will also match `\r\n` or `\r`.

The `case_insensitive` parameter will also activate the corresponding `i` flag
on the regular expression.

Note that if the configuration is provided as JSON you must escape the `\`
character. To search for `\s` you need to write `"search": "\\s"`.


**Multiple replacements**

This transformer allows to replace a single search string. It is possible to
use the `mapping.search_replace` transformer to run a series of replacements.

case_insensitive.description: Whether the search should be case insensitive.

regex.description: Treat the search param as a regular expression

source__aspen.jobs.description:
This source implements Aspen XML job feeds.

Aspen provides an index page listing all XML urls to download.
This source will stream objects from each URL returned by the index page.

The XML will be searched with the `job_selector` param. This is expected to
return a list of node that will be the objects returned from the source.

Each object will be converted to a key value dictionary using a single level
of properties.

For instance, with the following xml:

```xml
<jobs>
  <job>
    <job_id>123</job_id>
    <title>Senior Developer</title>
  </job>
</jobs>
```

With a `job_selector` defined as `/jobs/job`, the source will return a single
object, whose data will be defined as:

```json
{
  "job_id": "123",
  "title": "Senior Developer"
}
```

id_property.description: The property name to use as the provider reference.

job_selector.description: An XPath expression to select the job nodes.

url.description: The XML feed endpoint without the `?page`.

transformer__filter_object.description:
This transformer will mark the current object as ignored if the input is
_falsy_.

max_objects.description: The maximum number of objects to fetch from the source

object_name.description: The path/key to use when setting the name for an object

transformer__key_equals.description:
Returns `true` if the value associated to the `key` in the input object is
equal to the given `value`.

key.description: The key containing the value to compare.

value.description: The value to compare with the value under `key`.

source__chanel.jobs.description:
A specific client for pulling jobs from cid.clasp-infra.com using a double
authentication mechanism.

Uses `curl/8.4.0` as the `User-Agent` header value for the resource
endpoint.

oauth_client_id_ref.description: The secret reference for the Oauth client ID

oauth_client_secret_ref.description: The secret reference for the Oauth client secret

oauth_endpoint.description: The authentication base URL without any path, for instance `https://example.com`.

ocp_apim_subscription_key_ref.description: The secret reference for the Ocp-Apim-Subscription-Key header

resource_client_id_ref.description: The client ID secret reference to authenticate in the resource endpoint

resource_endpoint.description: The data base URL to fetch objects from without any path, for instance `https://example.com`

resource_secret_name_ref.description: The secret reference for the 'Secret Name' header value to authenticate in the resource endpoint

resource_username.description: The username to use to authenticate to the resource endpoint, as plaintext.

transformer__write_input.description: Stores the input value in the data object at the given key.

key.description: The key or path to store the input value in.

nil_if_blank.description:
Write `nil` instead of the input when the input is an empty string or
a string that contains only whitespace characters.

transformer__join_list.description:
Takes a list of strings as input and returns the concatenation of all the
items in the list, separated by `glue`.

Any `null` value is ignored in the input list. If the input list is empty, or
contains only `null` values, it returns an empty string.

glue.description: The string to use between items.

transformer__read_key.description:
Returns a key or path from the object data.

If the key is not found, the transformer will return an error.

key.description: A key or path to read from the object data.

transformer__rename_key.description:
Updates a key at the root level of the object data. The old key is deleted
and the value is copied under the new key.

from_name.description: The key or path to rename.

target__welcome_jobs.jobs.description:
Uses the Internal API of Welcome Jobs to create and archive jobs.

* Creations and updates are managed by the `/api/v1/internal/jobs` route that
  implements a simple upsert CRUD mechanism. Returned status code depends on
  the result of the upsert and can be 200 or 201.
* Deletions are sent to the `/api/v1/internal/jobs/archive` route, a shortcut to patch
  the status of a job only. The `404` errors are ignored and treated as a
  valid deletion.

endpoint.description: The base url for Welcome Jobs. That is, the full `<scheme>://<hostname>:<port><optional path>`. The `WELCOME_JOBS_ENDPOINT` environment variable will be used if not provided.

orga_wa_reference.description: The Welcome Accounts UUID for the organization.

transformer__read_key_or_default.description:
Returns a key or path from the object data.

If the key is not found, or is null, the default value is returned. If the
default value is not provided, a null value is returned.

It is also possible to return the default value only if the key is not found
in the data, and return null if the key is found but the value is null. This
is controlled by the `allow_null` parameter.

allow_null.description: When true, null values will be returned when found, instead of the default value.

default.description: Default value to return if the key is not found.

key.description: A key or path to read from the object data.

transformer__array.lookup.description:
Returns a value from the input array at a given index. Indices start at `0`.

Returns a null value if the index is not found.

Negative indices are supported. `-1` is the last item, `-2` is the one before.
Negative indices lower than the negative lenght will return a null value
(index `-3` with an array of `2` items).

transformer__mapping.match_translate.description:
Searches in the mapping for a key that matches the input and defines a value
for the selected column and returns the column value.

* String and case insentive string keys match the input if they are contained
  in the input.
* Regex and case insensitive regex keys match the input if the regex matches
  the input.

Mapping entries that match the input but do not define a value for the
specified column are ignored, and the search continues over subsequent keys.

column.description: The column to use for translations.

transformer__input.description:
Returns the given value as-is.

This utility allows to start a transform step with a raw value as input
instead of starting from the object data.

value.description:
This can be any value.

Note that the configuration is serialized as JSON so the value must be
JSON-serializable.

transformer__string.change_case.description: Returns the input string with its case set to the `case` parameter.

case.description: The desired output case, accepts 'lower' and 'upper'

transform_step__step.transform.description: Execute a suite of transformations with the current object data.

name.description: An optional name used for UI purposes only.

transformer__array.find.description:
Returns the first value from a list for which the given transform sequence
outputs a truthy value.

run.description: A list of transformers to apply to each item of the input list.

var.description: Bind the input to a variable

transformer__mapping.match_any.description:
Returns `true` if any key matches the input, `false` otherwise. No custom
column is used nor returned.

* String and case insentive string keys match the input if they are contained
  in the input.
* Regex and case insensitive regex keys match the input if the regex matches
  the input.

transformer__string.collect.description:
Accepts a list of keys as parameters and returns all compatible values under
those keys from the object data in a flat list.

The compatible values are strings and numbers. Numbers will be converted to
strings in the final output.

If a key points to a list or a sub-object, all values are also collected
recursively. Note that only _values_ are returned from objects, no _key_ will
be part of the returned list of strings.

keys.description: The list of keys to extract.

transformer__get_flag.description:
Returns `true` if the defined variable is truthy, that is everything except
`nil` and `false`.

Returns `false` otherwise. It does not fail if the variable does not exist.

var.description: The variable name to check for truthiness.

transformer__exclude_object.description:
This transformer will mark the current object as ignored if the input is
_truthy_.

transformer__foreach.description: Allows to apply other transformers to each item of an input collection.

run.description: A list of transformers to apply to each item of the input list.

var.description: Bind the input to a variable

transformer__cache.description:
This transformer implements a cache to share data between different object
transformations for a single run.

Once the transform sequence executes successfully and outputs a value, this
transformer will return that same value whenever it is called for subsequent
objects of the same run.

No value is stored in cache until the inner transform sequence executes
successfully, so it will be executed for each object as long as it fails.

If you need to use multiple caches in a transformation configuration, make
sure to use a different cache `key`. On the other hand, if you want to reuse
the same cache in multiple place inside the transformation, reuse the same
`key`.


#### Disclaimers

* The cache is used per run and not per object, which means that **it is
  highly discouraged to use transformers that modify the object data** in the
  given transform sequence, as it will only executed for the first successful
  object.
* The cache value will be stored as long as the inner transform sequence
  succeeds for a given object, even if the transformation for that object
  fails in a subsequent transformer.

Please use the cache with care.

key.description: A cache identifier. All instances of this transformer using the same key will share the same data.

run.description: The transformations to execute whose output value will be stored in the cache

transformer__delete_keys.description: Delete keys from the object data.

keys.description: The list of keys to delete.

target__welcome_kit.jobs.description:
This target sends the object data as a job according to the Welcome Kit
Internal API description of a job.

The data will be validated according to the OpenAPI spec schema defined the
`wk` Ruby on Rails application.

It uses a dedicated endpoint of the Internal API of Welcome Kit to create and
archive jobs.

* Creations and updates are managed by the `/api/v3/internal/etl/jobs` route that
  implements a simple upsert CRUD mechanism. Returned status code depends on
  the result of the upsert and can be 200 or 201.
* Deletions are sent to the `/api/v3/internal/etl/jobs` route, a shortcut to patch the
  status of a job only. The `404` errors are ignored and treated as a valid
  deletion.

apply_url_tracker.description:
A query string appended to the `apply_url` of the job if provided.
It may start with an `?`, merging onto the `apply_url` query string if
present is supported.

endpoint.description:
The base url for Welcome Kit.

That is, the full `<scheme>://<hostname>:<port><optional path>`.
The `WELCOME_KIT_ENDPOINT` environment variable will be used if not
provided.

transformer__array.join.description:
Takes a list of strings as input and returns the concatenation of all the
items in the list, separated by `glue`.

Any `null` value is ignored in the input list. If the input list is empty, or
contains only `null` values, it returns an empty string.

glue.description: The string to use between items.

transformer__get_var.description:
Looks up the given variable in the current scope and returns its value.

A scope is defined at each level of the transformation:

* The outermost `transform` definition for a configuration.
* A preset included in that transform.
* A preset included in another preset.
* The level of a `foreach` transformer.
* Other macros such as `if` may define scopes as well.

**Variables are inherited from the parent scopes.**

For instance, if the transformation uses presets `A` and `B`, and preset `A`
uses preset `A.1`:

* Variables defined at the top level are visible anywhere.
* Variables defined in preset `A` (or passed as the `vars` params for the
  preset) are visible in `A` and `A.1` but _not_ in `B` or at the top level
  (variables are cleaned at the end of the scope).
* Variables defined in `B` are not visible in `A`, `A.1` or at the top level.

Also, variables are not visible before they are defined. They are not
initialized at the beginning of the transformation step.

**Variables are shadowing**

It is possible to define a variable with a name that already exists in the
parent scope. The new value will be visible in the scope it is defined, and in
the inner scopes. At the end of the defining scope, the value will be clean
and the parent scope will see the old value.

Example:

* The outer transform uses `set_var` to create the `who` variable to
  `"Alice"`.
* The outer scope uses a preset, passing `{"vars": {"who": "Bob"}}` in the
  params.
* The preset will get `"Bob"` when using `get_var` with `who` for the key.
* After the preset transformations are applied, back in the outer transform
  scope, `get_var` will return `"Alice"`.


**Dotpath syntax support**

`get_var` supports passing a path as the `var` param.

If the context defines a variable `a` with the value `{"b": {"c": "hello"}}`
then it is possible to pass `"a.b.c"` as the `var` param to get `"hello"` as a
result.

var.description: The name or path of the variable to output.

transformer__string.split.description:
Divides a string into parts based on a pattern. Returns an array with the
different parts.

The pattern is a string of zero or more characters. Regular expressions are
not supported for now.

The pattern is parsed as an escaped string, so `\\n` will be interpreted as a
`\n`, while `\n` still represent itself, both are treated the same way.

pattern.description: The separator to split the string with.

trim.description: Remove empty strings from the array results.

transformer__ai.detect_profession.description:
Accepts keys to look for in the object data and calls the Profession Wizard
API to fetch a profession.

All given keys must be present in the object data and contain a string value,
otherwise an error is returned.

The WK-compatible profession reference is returned as output.

description_key.description: The key to look for in the object data to get the job description sent to Profession Wizard.

endpoint.description: The Profession Wizard endpoint as `<scheme>://<hostname>:<port><optional path>`. The `PROFESSION_WIZARD_ENDPOINT` environment variable will be used if not provided.

language_key.description: The key to look for in the object data to get the language sent to Profession Wizard.

name_key.description: The key to look for in the object data to get the job name sent to Profession Wizard.

transformer__string.slugify.description:
Transforms an input string into a slug without whitespace.

This tranformer will fail if the slug would be empty. For instance a blank
string like `"     "` will be converted to `"-----"` and then trimmed,
returning `""`, which is not considered a valid slug.

separator.description: The string used to replace whitespace.

transformer__http_get.description:
Accepts an URL as input, executes a `GET` request and returns the response
body.

retry.description:
When `true`, the request will be retried 3 times for a total of 4 attempts,
with an exponetial backoff delay.

transformer__string.clean_html.description:
HTML Cleanup utility allowing for standardization and normalization of HTML
documents.

All default parameters are designed to output structured text for
descriptions, articles, _etc._ and not intended to work with full web pages or
complex HTML layouts ; though it can be done with explicit configuration.

The cleaner executes multiple operations on the HTML document:

* **Filter tags**: This operation is controlled with the `reject_tags` and
  `allow_tags` parameters. The tags _and their whole content_ is removed from
  the document.
* **Unwrap tags**: This operatoin will replace unwanted tags with their
  content. For instance, unwrapping `div` tags will lift all the div's inner
  content in place of the div.  The `script` and `style` tags can be set for
  unwrapping but their content is always removed in that case.
* **Strip attributes**: This operation will remove all attributes from all
  tags, except those defined in the `allow_attributes` parameter.
* **Validate attributes**: This operation will verify the content of
  attributes and remove non-matching cases:
    - `href` attributes must be an absolute URL with `https://`.
    - `src` attributes must be an absolute URL with `https://`.
* **Smart grouping**: This operation will try to rebuild article-like content
  by:
    - Wrapping free text content in a `p` tag if not already wrapped. Any `br`
      or `hr` tag in the content flow will start a new `p` tag.  This
      operations is made on all tags listed in the `unwrap_tags` parameter, as
      well as the root level.
    - Fixing `ul` and `li` wrapping. All `li` sequences not wrapped in an `ul`
      will be wrapped, and other content than `li` found inside an `ul` will
      be lifted up. If some content appears between `li` tags, multuple `ul`
      tags will be created.
* **Filter empty tags**: This operation will remove all empty tags from the
  document, that is, tags with no children or only whitespace text-node
  children.
* **Prettify**: The final HTML is formatted to ease further usage with
  parsers.

allow_attributes.description:
HTML attributes to keep. All unlisted attributes will be removed from
all tags.

allow_tags.description:
HTML tags to keep. If empty, all tags are allowed, except those defined
in `reject_tags`. If not empty, the `reject_tags` parameter is ignored.

prettify.description:
Whether to pretty-format the final HTML document. This is useful for
debugging and further parsing.

reject_tags.description:
HTML tags to remove. Matched tags and all their content is removed. This
parameter is ignored if `allow_tags` is not empty.

remove_empty_tags.description:
HTML tags to remove if their content is empty, _i.e._, no children or
only text children with withespace.

smart_content_grouping.description:
Whether to enable content grouping, such as wrapping body content in `p`
tags or forcing `ul` around `li` tags.

unwrap_tags.description:
HTML tags to unwrap. Those tags will be removed but their content
will be lifted up in the parent scope.

transformer__mapping.translate.description:
Searches for the input in the mapping group and return the value if found in
the specified `column`.

Otherwise returns an error.

Note that the first mapping entry whose search key is equal to the input will
be used. If the entry does not define a value for the desired column, the
transformer will return an error.

column.description: The column to use for translations

transform_step__step.preset.description:
Execute a transformation preset.

Presets are containers other transform steps and can even invoke other
presets. They are useful to define reusable parts of a transformation pipeline.

preset.description: The reference of the preset to use.

vars.description: A key/value map of variables to be defined in the preset scope.
